title: God's Enduring Mercy
shortSummary: Psalm 118 is a powerful hymn of thanksgiving celebrating God's steadfast love and deliverance. It emphasizes trusting in the Lord over human strength and highlights God's saving power in times of distress. This chapter also prophetically points to Christ as the cornerstone rejected by men but exalted by God.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - United Monarchy period, traditionally attributed to King David

keyCharacters.name: Israel
keyCharacters.description: The nation called to proclaim God's enduring mercy and faithfulness.

keyCharacters.name: House of Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The priestly family invoked to declare God's mercy, representing the religious leadership.

keyCharacters.name: The Psalmist
keyCharacters.description: The speaker of the psalm who expresses personal distress, deliverance, and praise to God.

keyCharacters.name: The Builders
keyCharacters.description: Those who rejected the stone, symbolizing opposition to God's chosen cornerstone.

definitions.definition: God’s steadfast love and compassion shown to sinners, enduring forever.
The foundational stone in a building; metaphorically, Christ as the essential foundation of faith.
Disciplined or corrected by God for the purpose of spiritual growth and refinement.
Temporary dwellings or tents; here, places where the righteous rejoice and worship God.
A biblical symbol of power and authority, representing God’s mighty intervention.

outline.heading: Call to Praise God’s Mercy
outline.description: The psalm opens with a communal call for Israel, the priests, and all who fear the Lord to declare His enduring mercy, establishing the theme of thanksgiving.

outline.heading: God’s Deliverance in Distress
outline.description: The psalmist recounts personal deliverance from enemies and distress, affirming confidence in God’s protection and strength.

outline.heading: Victory and Praise for God’s Salvation
outline.description: Celebration of God’s victorious power and salvation, including acknowledgment of divine discipline that leads to life rather than death.

outline.heading: Invitation to Enter God’s Righteousness
outline.description: A plea for access to the gates of righteousness and a declaration of praise for God’s salvation.

outline.heading: The Rejected Stone Becomes the Cornerstone
outline.description: A prophetic declaration that the stone rejected by builders (Christ) becomes the cornerstone, highlighting God’s marvelous work and the joy of the day He has made.

outline.heading: Blessing and Exaltation of the Lord
outline.description: A final plea for salvation and prosperity, blessing those who come in the name of the Lord, and concluding with praise for God’s enduring goodness and mercy.

application: Trust in God’s mercy and faithfulness above all human strength or leadership, especially in times of trouble.
Respond to God’s deliverance with heartfelt praise and public declaration of His salvation.
Recognize that God’s discipline is for our spiritual growth and leads to life, not destruction.
Celebrate each day as a gift from God, rejoicing in His sovereign work and presence.

keyVerses.text: The LORD is on my side; I will not fear: what can man do unto me?
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the believer’s confidence and fearlessness because of God’s presence and protection.

keyVerses.text: The stone which the builders refused is become the head stone of the corner.
keyVerses.significance: A prophetic reference to Christ as the cornerstone rejected by men but exalted by God, foundational to the Church.

keyVerses.text: This is the day which the LORD hath made; we will rejoice and be glad in it.
keyVerses.significance: A call to rejoice in God’s sovereign provision and the gift of each new day.

keyVerses.text: O give thanks unto the LORD; for he is good: for his mercy endureth for ever.
keyVerses.significance: The psalm’s concluding call to thanksgiving, highlighting God’s unchanging goodness and eternal mercy.
